name: Chernobyl Solar
note: On the site of the former nuclear reactor

name: Tesla's proposed virtual power plant
note: 50,000 homes with solar panels and battery storage

name: Quaid-e-Azam
note: Named in honor of Quaid-e-Azam Muhammad Ali Jinnah, the founder of Pakistan. Criticised for the amount of water used to keep its panels clean and efficient.

name: Tengger Desert
note: Covers 3.2% of the land area of the Tengger desert. Dubbed the "Great Wall of Solar".

name: Noor
note: largest CSP plant in the world

name: Shakti Sthala
note: Largest in the world. As far as I can tell, 2000MW should be online now. 700,000 Indian households

name: Gunung Salak
note: Indonesia's geothermal potential is huge, but under-exploited. Profits have been used to fund a boarding school for girls in the rural area where it is sited.

name: Larderello
note: Oldest geothermal power plant in the world, built in 1913

name: Polaniec
note: powered by agricultural byproducts and wood residue

name: Rodenhuize 4
note: Built as a coal plant, converted to biomass between 2005 and 2010.

name: Drax
note: The first power station in the UK to be fuelled solely by wood. Converted from coal between 2008 and 2018.

name: Utgrunden
note: offshore. Built in 2000, decomissioned due to old age in 2018.

name: Muppandal Farm
note: onshore, located on the southern tip of India, powered by seasonal monsoon winds from the Arabian Sea.

name: Gwynt y Môr
note: offshore, 4th largest operating wind farm in the world

name: Vineyard Wind project
note: onshore, Massachusetts, largest offshore, completed in 2021

name: Dogger Bank
note: offshore, finished in 2025, 23041 MWh calc based on 8410Gwh per year. Water depth in the area is just 15m.

name: Arnot
note: Located on top of Arnot coal mine, one of the largest coal reserves in Africa.

name: Yeongheung
note: Its cooling systems drive a trio of small hydroelectric plants.

name: Tiachung
note: The largest operating coal plant in the world

name: Rabigh
note: Attached to a major desalination plant

name: Chita
note: At 3,996MW installed capacity, the Chita thermal power station located in Chita, Aichi, Japan, is the world’s fifth biggest natural gas power plant.

name: Dah-Tarn
note: The 4,384MW Dah-Tarn (Tatan) power plant located in Guanyin, Taoyuan, in Northern Taiwan is the world’s fourth biggest gas-fired power plant.

name: Futtsu
note: The 5,040MW Futtsu liquefied natural gas (LNG)-based thermal power station located in Chiba, Japan, is currently the world’s seventh biggest thermal power plant.

name: Kawagoe
note: Chubu Electric Power Company’s Kawagoe thermal power station located in Kawagoe, Mie, Japan, with 4,802 MW installed capacity, ranks as the world’s third biggest gas-fired power station.

name: Surgutskaya GRES-2
note: Built in 1979 to power the extraction of minerals in Siberia. At 5,597MW installed capacity, Surgutskaya GRES-2 (Sugrut-2), a combined cycle power plant located in the Russian city of Surgut, is the world’s biggest gas-fired power station. The facility is owned and operated by E.ON Russia.

name: Torness
note: Shut down in 2011 by a swarm of jellyfish.

name: Chernobyl
note: One reactor suffered major damage during the 1986 accident. The other three continued operation, and the plant was finally shut down permanently in 2000.

name: Fukushima Daiichi
note: Suffered major damage from the 2011 Japan tsunami. Still offline.

name: Palo Verde
note: largest US nuclear power station in USA

name: Kashiwazaki-Kariwa
note: largest nuclear plant in the world (by MW), currently shut!

name: Gravelines
note: 6th largest in world, 2nd largest in Europe

name: Zaporizhia
note: 5th largest, 20% of country's electricity, largest in Europe

name: Hanul
note: 4th largest, due to increase to 8608MW in 2018?

name: Bruce
note: Ontario, 2nd biggest in the world. Largest operating reactor in the world.

name: Hoover Dam
note: Contains enough concrete to build a road between the west and east coasts of the US. Hoover wasn't invited to the dam's dedication ceremony.

name: Guri
note: Provides 70-80% of Venezuela's power. Its failure in 2019 caused widespread blackouts. The government blamed it on sabotage. Experts blamed it on lack of maintainence.

name: Baihetan Dam
note: Under construction, expected to be complete in 2021.

name: Itaipu Dam
note: The Itaipu Dam produced the most energy of hydroelectric plant in the world as of 2016, setting a new world record of 103,098,366 megawatt hours (MWh), and surpassed the Three Gorges Dam plant in energy production in 2015 and 2016.
